author: By Kate Kelly
title: Security Is Tighter for Trump Rally at Site of July Assassination Attempt
description: The Secret Service has deployed large forces to protect former President Donald J. Trump as he prepares to hold a rally in Butler, Pa., where a gunman attacked him in July.
content: The U.S. Secret Service has deployed hundreds of agents and local law enforcement officials to guard former President Donald J. Trump when he returns to Butler, Pa., for a rally Saturday evening, hoping to seal up the holes that left him vulnerable to a would-be assassin at the same venue in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: David Burnham, Times Reporter Who Exposed Police Graft, Dies at 91
description: Tipped off by the detective Frank Serpico, he wrote an explosive series on police corruption in New York City, sparking an investigation by the Knapp commission.
content: David Burnham, a former investigative reporter for The New York Times whose exposé of corruption in the New York City Police Department in 1970 led to public hearings; tarnished top officials, including the mayor; and inspired the movie “Serpico,” about Mr. Burnham’s chief source, Detective Frank Serpico, died on Tuesday at his home in Spruce Head, Maine. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: JD Smirks His Way Into the Future
description: The misogynist ticket takes a shot at Kamala for dancing — and being a woman.
content: When I’ve covered the campaigns of women on presidential tickets, the question invariably arises: “Is she tough enough to be commander in chief?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Michigan Father Dies in Israeli Airstrike in Lebanon, Family Says
description: Kamel Ahmad Jawad, a U.S. citizen, was remembered by friends and relatives as someone who chose to stay behind to help others who couldn’t flee.
content: Kamel Ahmad Jawad remained calm, even as Israeli missiles rained down around him in his hometown in southern Lebanon, thousands of miles from his other home, Dearborn, Mich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Cecilia Kang
title: The Troubling Quiet of North Carolina’s Cell Service Outages
description: Service has been restored in some areas after Hurricane Helene, but many people are still unable to communicate by phone, which has hampered relief efforts, worried loved ones and complicated daily life.
content: John Tressler stood next to what was left of his storm-battered deli, part of which had collapsed in the torrents of a raging river, and waited to meet a relief crew bringing a much-needed supply of food into Swannanoa, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,205
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 6, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Macron Calls for Halting Weapons to Israel for Gaza Conflict
description: The French leader’s comments drew the condemnation of Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and reflected the growing international concern over Israel’s expanding conflicts in the region.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France called for an “immediate and lasting” cease-fire in Lebanon and said countries should stop shipping weapons to Israel for use in Gaza, adding to international pressure on Israel to do more to protect civilians and work toward an end to fighting in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: As Lawmaker Claims Trump’s Shooting Was Inside Job, G.O.P. Indulges Him
description: Representative Eli Crane, a first-term Arizona Republican, has emerged as the chief right-wing voice pushing conspiracy theories about the Trump assassination attempts.
content: He posits that there is a mole within Donald J. Trump’s Secret Service detail and warns that the former president should bolster his private security to “watch the watchers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans and Maddie McGarvey
title: Supporters Who Watched as Trump Was Shot Prepare to Welcome Him Back
description: Donald J. Trump is returning to Butler, Pa., to hold another rally at the site where he was nearly assassinated in July in an attack that killed a man and wounded two others.
content: When the balloons descended on Donald J. Trump at the finale of the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Jondavid Longo, the mayor of Slippery Rock, Pa., was on the floor of the arena. As a few balloons popped, he glanced at the other Pennsylvania delegates he knew who, like him, had been at Mr. Trump’s rally in Butler, Pa., five days earlier. More than one of them winced at the sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: There Are Layers to This
description: Natan Last goes toe to toe with us in this challenging puzzle.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman
title: 30 Days Out, the Harris and Trump Campaigns Brace for ‘Trench Warfare’
description: With tight contests in all seven battleground states, the candidates are pressing for a few thousand votes that could sway the outcome of the entire election.
content: As Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump begin the final 30-day push for the White House, they are locked in a neck-and-neck race from the Rust Belt to the Sun Belt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen and Alicia Parlapiano
title: A Nation of Homebodies
description: A recent study shows Americans are spending notably more time at home, a trend that started long before the pandemic.
content: It turns out we aren’t just bowling alone — we’re bowling at home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Assistance Slow to Reach Hard-Hit Latino Communities
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 5, 2024
content: “We don’t have a lot right now, but we have each other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Aides Say Trump Resisted Sending Federal Funds After California Wildfires
description: He changed his mind after being shown data that his supporters in the state had been affected, the former officials said. One called his approach “red states vs. blue states.”
content: As California battled the deadliest wildfire in its history in 2018, Donald J. Trump, then the president, initially opposed unlocking federal funding for the state, according to two former Trump administration officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: How Gender Became the Election’s Crucial Fault Line
description: Harris could be the first female president. But it’s Trump and Vance who are playing the gender card.
content: In an alternate universe, Nikki Haley is running for president against Kamala Harris in the true Year of the Woman. In our world, Haley is on the sidelines wishing Republicans would stop alienating a large swath of voters. “Donald Trump and JD Vance need to change the way they speak about women,” Haley said on “Fox & Friends” in September, when she was asked why Trump and Vance were trailing by 14 points among female voters. “When you call even a Democrat woman dumb, Republican women get their backs up, too.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Biden Sought Peace but Facilitated War
description: Netanyahu repeatedly rolled the American president, leading us all to the precipice of a much larger war.
content: When Israel defied America’s appeals for restraint by invading Lebanon a few days ago, a reporter asked President Biden if he was comfortable with what had unfolded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: In North Carolina Town Hall, Trump Makes a Series of Promises to Appeal to Veterans
description: Donald J. Trump answered preselected questions from a pro-military crowd who echoed his false claims and approved of his vow to conduct massive deportations of undocumented immigrants.
content: At the end of his town hall in North Carolina on Friday, former President Donald J. Trump was asked by a former Air Force pilot whether he would create a panel to keep “woke generals” out of the Defense Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benny Gantz
title: Benny Gantz: What the World Needs to Understand About Iran
description: Now is the time to bolster regional cooperation and make a broad effort to confront Iran.
content: Oct. 7, 2023, marked the worst tragedy for the state of Israel and the Jewish people since the Holocaust. Some 1,200 people were murdered in Israel, and approximately 250 people were taken hostage on a single day; 101 of those souls are still held captive in Gaza. Hezbollah in Lebanon began its attack on the north of Israel the very next day, forcing nearly 70,000 Israelis from their homes. Iran, launching attacks first on April 13 and again on Oct. 1, has sent millions of Israelis into the safety of their shelters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: America Needs a President
description: The sidelining of the White House in global crisis spots is a big red flag.
content: Last week’s column was devoted to uncertainties about how the next president would handle the deteriorating situation in Ukraine, where America’s proxy and ally is slowly losing ground to Russia, while the United States seems trapped by its commitment to a maximal victory and unable to pivot to a strategy for peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Slotkin
title: To Understand Trump vs. Harris, You Must Know These American Myths
description: It’s as if we are living in two different countries, each with a different understanding of who counts as American.
content: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are making their appeals to the American electorate on the basis of personality, character and policy. But they are also framing themselves as actors in the American story — the events of the recent past and the deeper narrative of U.S. history carried by the symbol-rich stories of our national mythology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: With ‘Megalopolis,’ the Flop Era Returns to Cinemas
description: Plenty of movies bomb, but Francis Ford Coppola’s latest is part of a different class of box office failures.
content: Just before previews began at a Lower Manhattan theater on a recent Saturday night, Tazer Army reflected on the Francis Ford Coppola movie “Megalopolis” before even seeing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Widow of Man Killed in July Attack on Trump Returns for Rally
description: Helen Comperatore, whose husband, Corey Comperatore, was killed when a gunman tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump, returned to honor her husband’s memory.
content: Helen Comperatore, the widow of Corey Comperatore, the former volunteer fire chief who was killed when a gunman tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump on July 13 at a rally in Butler, Pa., returned to the venue on Saturday when Mr. Trump came back for another rally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Heffernan
title: Get Your Mind Into the Gutter
description: Autumn is for addressing one of the most neglected parts of your home.
content: Last winter, after finding big puddles in our New Jersey home’s cellar for the third time, my wife and I called a local plumber. He gave the cellar a once-over, confirmed that our sump pump was in working order, and then surprised us by suggesting we take a look outside the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 483
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 6, 2024
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: After Helene’s ‘Historic’ Damage, Appalachian Trail May Need Years to Recover
description: Downed trees and flooding have left the trail impassable in many of the 14 states on its route.
content: As the scope of devastation caused by Hurricane Helene comes into focus, an American landmark that dozens of towns benefit from is facing historic destruction: the Appalachian Trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaad D'Souza
title: GloRilla, Hip-Hop’s Master Motivator, Rounds Out Her Message
description: Self-empowerment rhymes catapulted her onto rap’s A-list. On “Glorious,” her debut LP, she’s hoping that showing more sides of her personality will help her stay there.
content: GloRilla is always on the clock these days. Last month, the rapper born Gloria Hallelujah Woods stomped and bounced through her hits “Yeah Glo!” and “TGIF” at the MTV Video Music Awards, then spent the next morning at a photo shoot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: 5 Takeaways From Melania Trump’s Book
description: Shining a little more light on her mysterious life, her memoir details her support for abortion rights, her doubts about the 2020 election and her explanation for that “I really don’t care” jacket.
content: Melania Trump’s new memoir offers a few new glimpses into a life she has carefully walled off from the public, but readers hoping to understand one of the most mysterious first ladies in modern history will not make it past the gilded front gate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Reisman
title: I’m a Doctor. ChatGPT’s Bedside Manner Is Better Than Mine.
description: My job is no longer safe.
content: As a young, idealistic medical student in the 2000s, I thought my future job as a doctor would always be safe from artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books About Old Flames
description: Stephen McCauley’s novel about ex-spouses reuniting, in a sense; Jim Shepard’s noir about a fateful hit-and-run.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: How Walmart’s Donna Morris Manages the Largest Work Force in America
description: With 1.6 million U.S. employees under her watch, the company’s chief people officer faced a unique challenge just weeks into her new job: a pandemic.
content: More than 30 years into a career that had brought her to California and then Arkansas from her native Canada, Donna Morris could not have chosen a more challenging time to take on the role of chief people officer of Walmart. It was February 2020 — a couple of weeks before the coronavirus pandemic upended the world and laid bare an uncertain future for both workers and the retail industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Harris Meets With Arab and Muslim Leaders in Michigan
description: The meeting, which took place backstage, came as Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign ramped up efforts to appeal directly to Arab and Muslim voters in the final weeks before the election.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday met with Arab and Muslim leaders while campaigning in Michigan, a crucial battleground state where roiling discontent over the United States’ backing of Israel’s war in Gaza and its escalating attacks in Lebanon could threaten her support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Campaigning for Harris, Women Share Their Abortion Stories With Neighbors
description: The Harris campaign is trying to transform women in battleground states into an organizing force who can drive their friends and family to the polls.
content: One by one, the women shared their stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: From Melania Trump: Modeling, Motherhood and a Brazen Whitewash of a Presidency
description: Slim and full of obfuscations, her memoir touches on business ventures and raising her son, but barely grapples with the mysteries of her marriage.
content: White House memoirs tend to go on a bit. Melania Trump’s is slim, as befits an erstwhile fashion model who prepared for her husband’s 2017 inauguration with “strong espresso and a light breakfast of fruit,” but gravely out of shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sridhar Pappu
title: Will the ‘SmartLess’ Podcast Be the Biggest Role of Their Careers?
description: Started during the pandemic, this venture is the first step in a media empire being built by the actors Sean Hayes, Will Arnett and Jason Bateman.
content: It’s a warm Saturday afternoon in the middle of August, and the actors Jason Bateman, Sean Hayes and Will Arnett are gathered on the stage of the Stephen Talkhouse, a popular music venue in the Long Island summer resort town of Amagansett, telling stories and swapping insults with Howard Stern, the longtime radio personality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘Nobody Wants This’ Pits Jewish Women Against ‘Shiksas.’ Nobody Wins.
description: Except maybe Jewish men.
content: The derisive word for a male gentile is shegetz. I didn’t know the term until I married one. Even though my family is 100 percent Jewish and my brother took a DNA test to prove it, up to that point, I had only ever heard the female equivalent of the word: shiksa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler and Tania Ganguli
title: What an Escalating Middle East Conflict Could Mean for the Global Economy
description: The biggest risk is a sustained increase in oil prices.
content: For nearly a year since the Hamas attack on Israel on Oct. 7 and the start of the fighting in Gaza, investment strategists have warned that a wider war could break out in the Middle East, crimping the world’s oil supply and sending shock waves throughout the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: Demure Might Not Be Just a Passing Fad
description: Many brands in their spring 2025 collections offered ladylike alternatives to the flashy and revealing clothing that has proliferated in recent years.
content: Oversize bows where six months ago there was cleavage. Flouncy, lacy, columnar dresses instead of skintight styles. More knee-length shorts, fewer micro mini skirts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Al Pacino Is Still Going Big
description: A conversation with the legendary actor about, well, everything.
content: Al Pacino has been one of the world’s greatest, most influential actors for more than 50 years. He’s audacious. He’s outrageous. He’s Al Pacino, and I’m pretty sure you know what that entails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison McCann
title: How a Gardener at a Brooklyn Park Spends Her Sundays
description: Eve Brooks, the gardener at Herbert Von King Park, spends her day tending to her pet turtle, listening to Sam Cooke and getting down in the dirt at the park.
content: A decade ago, Eve Brooks was unemployed and looking for help. A caseworker mentioned that the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation had several job training programs, including a six-month horticulture program. She immediately enrolled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Urges Congress to Replenish Disaster Relief Funds Quickly
description: The president said a Small Business Administration program needed to help business owners recover from Hurricane Helene was set to run out of money in weeks, before Congress reconvenes.
content: President Biden urged members of Congress on Friday to provide emergency funding for the Small Business Administration, saying the agency is critically low on money needed to help people in communities devastated by Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Emily Flitter
title: Hit by Disaster? How to Get What You Deserve From Insurers or FEMA
description: Experts offered plenty of advice about ways to make the disaster-recovery process work. Here’s what to do and what to avoid.
content: If your home was damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Helene, the most daunting challenge may still be ahead: Getting your insurance company, or the federal government, to give you the money you’re entitled to receive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: As 23andMe Struggles, Concerns Surface About Its Genetic Data
description: A plummet in the company’s valuation and a recent board resignation have raised questions about the future of genetic data collected from millions of customers.
content: The genetic testing company 23andMe, once valued at $6 billion, is facing an uncertain future after a drop in share prices, a recent board resignation and a data breach last year that affected nearly seven million customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Pro-Palestinian Group Is Relentless in Its Criticism of Israel, and It Isn’t Backing Down
description: Within Our Lifetime, a group formed by New York students, has galvanized pro-Palestinian activists who are calling for the end of Israel — and facing accusations of antisemitism.
content: Without even entering Grand Central Terminal’s soaring main hall on one Thursday evening in July, Nerdeen Kiswani and her pro-Palestinian protest group, Within Our Lifetime, managed to shut it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: Paris Hilton Is Becoming a Fixture at Walmart
description: A new line of handbags expands the offerings of her brand at the big-box chain. Plus, rare Birkenstocks and a pink suit you may have seen.
content: Paris Hilton is associated with many things — being an heiress, an entrepreneur, an activist and a Y2K fashion inspiration — but living on a budget is not often among them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Hundreds of Storm-Ravaged Roads, and No Timeline for Fixing Them
description: Repairing the roads in the region near the North Carolina-Tennessee border could take months. Some residents worry about the impact on the local economy.
content: The small roads made of dirt and rock had been there for generations, twisting byways that carried families up and down the mountains of western North Carolina. The asphalt highways were newer, built along cliffs and over rivers to connect the region with South Carolina and Tennessee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ever-Shrinking Condos Are the Choice of Investors in Toronto and Vancouver
description: A new report shows that small condo units are preferred by investors and that a lack of investor buyers may now be delaying new buildings.
content: There is a group of Canadians who want to see house prices continue to soar: investors. A report from Statistics Canada released this week details their outsize influence on the condominium markets in Vancouver and Toronto. And it’s an influence that may now be thwarting some new construction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio and Eve Sampson
title: What to Know: How Israel Could Retaliate Against Iran
description: Iran has a number of sensitive sites, including oil infrastructure, military installations and nuclear facilities.
content: Iran and Israel avoided direct confrontation for years, fighting a shadow war of secret sabotage and assassinations. But the two countries are now moving closer to open conflict, after the Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon this week and Tehran’s ballistic missile barrage on Israel, its second in less than six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia
title: The Problem With the Hurricane Category Rating
description: After Helene, it may be time to rethink how to communicate the risks posed by storms, especially extreme rain.
content: By the time Hurricane Helene reached western North Carolina a week ago, causing devastating floods, it was no longer a hurricane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Adam Entous
title: Behind Trump’s Views on Ukraine: Putin’s Gambit and a Political Grudge
description: The roots of Donald Trump’s animus toward Ukraine — an issue with profound consequences should he be elected again — can be found in a yearlong series of events spanning 2016 and 2017.
content: On July 7, 2017, after President Donald J. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia shook hands in Hamburg, Germany, to conclude their first face-to-face meeting, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson walked out of the sterile conference room, removed notes from his pocket and gave anxious White House aides a summary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack, Victoria Kim and Andrew Jacobs
title: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Lebanon as Fighting Spreads
description: With the region on edge about a possible Israeli retaliatory strike on Iran, U.S. Central Command hit targets in Yemen, and Israel ordered evacuations in Gaza.
content: As Israel escalated its fight against Hezbollah in Lebanon on Saturday, much of the Middle East was on edge, with many expecting an Israeli retaliatory strike on Iran as payback for its missile barrage on Israel earlier this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Marvin Schlachter, Record Executive Who Championed Disco, Dies at 90
description: In the 1960s, he helped get wide exposure for Black artists like Dionne Warwick. A decade later, he brought dance music from the clubs to radio success.
content: Marvin Schlachter, a music executive who helped launch Dionne Warwick and the Shirelles in the 1960s and who a decade later created one of the world’s most influential disco labels, bringing acts like Musique and France Joli to the masses, died on Sept. 19 in Manhattan. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Teacher’s Marks
description: John Kugelman makes the grade.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Christina Morales
title: Missing People, Power Outages, Ruined Roads: Issues Across the Southeast After Helene
description: The worst fallout from the hurricane is in western North Carolina, but at least five other states are grappling with their own intractable problems.
content: More than a week after Hurricane Helene made landfall as a Category 4 storm, state officials across the Southeast are scrambling to repair damaged electrical lines, roads and bridges affecting tens of thousands across the path of destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Ian Willms
title: A Menace to Motorists, but the ‘Noble’ Moose Is Adopted by Newfoundland
description: Introduced to the island 120 years ago, moose are involved in hundreds of collisions each year. But the huge animal is an accepted part of life here. “I suspect that they got squatters’ rights.”
content: Running into a moose when driving a car or truck is bad enough, but crashing into the giant animal while riding on two wheels can be worse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Adoptions by Foreign Parents
description: Readers discuss a guest essay by a Chinese adoptee.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: Ella Purnell Is a TV Star Who Hasn’t Lost Touch With Her Barista Roots
description: “Sometimes, before I go to bed,” the “Sweetpea” actress and executive producer said, “I think about how good my coffee’s going to be in the morning.”
content: You might think twice about overlooking the office wallflower after watching Ella Purnell play a sad sack gone sadist on the new Starz dramedy “Sweetpea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: My Go-To Weeknight Dinners
description: Grocery-store ice cream makes the list.
content: Hello, and thank you to Mia Leimkuhler for taking time off so I can go on and on about my favorite thing: recipes!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Did Nothing to Stop the Mob
description: “Stop the Steal” is about not trusting voters.
content: One of the key points in the unsealed legal filing presented by the special counsel Jack Smith in the criminal case against Donald Trump for conspiracy to subvert the 2020 presidential election is that both Trump and his allies were well aware that he had lost the election. The evidence, Smith says, shows that Trump knew he didn’t have a case. But rather than accept the verdict of the voting public, Trump led the effort to pressure officials to overturn election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Stefanos Chen
title: Big Business Saw an Ally in Eric Adams, and Overlooked His Issues
description: New York’s business community threw its support behind Mr. Adams, and continued backing him even as his legal problems began to threaten the governance of the city.
content: It wasn’t quite love at first sight, but it did not take New York’s business elite long to embrace Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Kamala Harris Visits North Carolina to Check on Hurricane Response
description: The vice president visited Charlotte, N.C., for an update on relief efforts after Hurricane Helene ravaged wide swaths of the Southeast.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris met with North Carolina and federal emergency officials on Saturday in Charlotte as she continued to help oversee the disaster response in the Southeast after Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Campus Protest Investigations Hang Over Schools as New Academic Year Begins
description: Dozens of discrimination complaints brought by conservative and pro-Jewish groups after the Oct. 7 attacks last year have spawned lengthy federal inquiries that some worry could chill free speech on campus.
content: With a new academic year well underway, more than 60 colleges and universities are still under federal investigation over antisemitic and Islamophobic incidents during the campus protests that swept the United States after the Oct. 7 attacks in Israel, according to the Department of Education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine’s Donbas Strategy: Retreat Slowly and Maximize Russia’s Losses
description: The idea is to use rope-a-dope tactics, letting Russian forces pound away until they have exhausted themselves. It’s far from clear if the Ukrainian strategy will succeed.
content: Throughout the year, Ukraine has lost a series of cities, towns and villages in its eastern Donbas region to Russia, typically withdrawing its troops after hard-fought battles that sometimes lasted for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad
title: As Israel Attacks, Many Lebanese Feel Dragged Into Someone Else’s War
description: In a crisis-racked country where sectarian tensions simmer, many worry that the conflict between Israel and the Shiite militia Hezbollah will end in more destruction for all.
content: When Hezbollah announced that its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah, had been killed in an Israeli airstrike, the talk among many of the group’s Shiite Muslim followers was of defiance and vengeance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Barrett, Jacob Flannick and Nick Madigan
title: A Deluge of Rain Poured Out of the Heavens. But There’s Still No Drinking Water.
description: City officials have refused to provide estimates of when the devastated water system in Asheville, N.C., will be back in operation.
content: Since their home lost running water around 2 p.m. on Sept. 27 from Hurricane Helene, Etiska Jackson and her husband, Jayme, have been driving back and forth between their home in Asheville, N.C., and her brother’s in Madison County, about 25 miles north. There, they wash their clothes, take showers and fetch water from a well to flush their toilet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Hurubie Meko
title: Former Gov. David Paterson of New York Assaulted in Manhattan
description: Mr. Paterson and his stepson suffered minor injuries in a street attack on Friday. The former governor was not believed to have been targeted in the assault, the police said.
content: David A. Paterson, a former governor of New York, and his stepson were injured in an assault on a Manhattan street on Friday evening, the Police Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Experian Wants You to Carry Its Debit Card Around. Be Wary.
description: There’s not a lot of love for the credit bureaus, so why would you want one of them in your wallet? Experian’s pitch: A slightly better credit score. Maybe.
content: In what universe would anyone want to whip out a debit card with the name of a credit bureau on it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green and Nick Simonite
title: James Magee, Creator of a Mysterious Desert Monument, Dies at 79
description: For 40 years, he built a group of stone and steel buildings in the West Texas desert to house his own monumental work. Only a few have been lucky enough to see it.
content: James Magee, an enigmatic and idiosyncratic artist and poet who spent four decades building a starkly beautiful monument of stone and steel in the West Texas desert that may be the most significant artwork most people have never heard of, died on Sept. 14 at his home in Fremont, Mich. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Can My Building Replace Our Keys With QR Codes and Facial Scans?
description: New York’s tenant data privacy law specifically addresses landlords’ use of ‘smart’ entry and intercom systems. Here’s what it says.
content: Q: The owner of my Manhattan apartment building is implementing an access system that unlocks doors only with QR codes, biometrics data, or facial scans. This system compromises tenants’ privacy and restricts access to dog walkers and other contractors. It is said to be susceptible to hacking, exposing us to burglaries. We are concerned about the collection, destination, and privacy of our data. Can our landlord force us to adopt this system?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: The Espresso Martini Has Nothing on These 2 Drinks
description: Make (or buy) cold brew, and put it to use in a nonalcoholic coffee tonic or a rich caffé amaro.
content: Despite its name (and temperature), cold brew’s season extends far beyond summer’s last breath — especially when put to use behind the bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Villages Spared a Soviet Nuclear Plant Are Split Over a U.S. One
description: A plan to place American-made reactors on a picturesque coastline has broad support in Poland — and in Washington — but the geopolitical calculations have run into local opposition.
content: It appeared to be a typical harvest festival on Poland’s picturesque Baltic coast, with women in traditional dress singing folk songs and local farmers displaying their wares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In Final Stretch, Biden Faces Some of the Biggest Crises of His Presidency
description: Even as President Biden recedes from view, some of the most consequential days of his term may be ahead of him.
content: President Biden was in the White House Situation Room on Tuesday morning, watching on video monitors as Iran fired waves of ballistic missiles at Israel. The wider war in the Middle East, which Mr. Biden had spent much of his presidency trying to avert, had arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hurtes and Arafat Mugabo
title: Deadly Marburg Virus Hits Rwanda’s Doctors and Nurses Hard
description: The Health Ministry has reported that 80 percent of the infected are health care professionals.
content: Rwanda’s fragile health care system could become overwhelmed by the deadly Marburg virus, doctors fear, because most of those currently infected are medical professionals, and some have already died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Fear Factors
description: Sometimes the scariest movies are the ones that depict the ordinary horrors of life.
content: I was fascinated to discover recently that each October, my friend Alex undertakes a spooky-season film festival, endeavoring to watch one horror flick for each day of the month. I do not expect that his roster includes the 2012 documentary “Part of Me,” a chronicle of the musician Katy Perry’s California Dreams concert tour. But I happened to watch that film this week, and it made me contemplate what, exactly, makes a movie frightening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Paul and George Etheredge
title: Can Hudson Square Reinvent Itself as New York City’s Next Hot Neighborhood?
description: Once known as a gritty, industrial area on Manhattan’s West Side, Hudson Square is now trying to lure new tenants and businesses, and create its own identity.
content: New York City is full of distinct neighborhoods, many competing for charm, hipness, quality of life and a good work-life balance. As a newcomer, and one that many city dwellers still haven’t heard of, Hudson Square is trying to create an identity separate from its culturally vibrant neighbors — SoHo to the east, the West Village to the north, TriBeCa to the south — that have long had curb appeal for businesses and new residents alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Hurricane Milton
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Milton.
content: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Milton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor, Claire Hogan, James Surdam and Laura Salaberry
title: Where Trump and Harris Stand on the Economy
description: Here’s where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand on economic issues like inflation, taxes and more. Maggie Astor, who covers politics for The New York Times, looks at the candidates’ views, proposals and records.
content: Here’s where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand on economic issues like inflation, taxes and more. Maggie Astor, who covers politics for The New York Times, looks at the candidates’ views, proposals and records.
source.name: The New York Times
